body:
Hi Jason,

Thanks for the suggestion.  The reason the full html template generates large files is that it is inlining the styling from the live notebook.  The full template is what is used to generate the "print preview".

We've tried to design nbconvert so that users can create and manage their own output templates.  We do not like to add new templates to nbconvert because it increases the amount of content that we have to manage and increases the scope of nbconvert.  What you're doing is exactly what we want our users to do, create and manager their own templates for whatever their exporting needs may be...

On a separate but related note, the idea of an easy web service for sharing user created templates has been discussed, but AFAIK nothing has come of it.

If you encounter something that you can't implement using the current framework (custom templates, filters, preprocessors, and postprocessors), then I suggest opening an issue.

The basic template is not a complete HTML document, but an HTML snippet for embedding in another context â€“ blog, etc. It should have no CSS at all. Perhaps 'snippet' or 'embeddable' would have been a better name.

> We've tried to design nbconvert so that users can create and manage their own output templates. We do not like to add new templates to nbconvert because it increases the amount of content that we have to manage and increases the scope of nbconvert. What you're doing is exactly what we want our users to do, create and manager their own templates for whatever their exporting needs may be...

I get the point and I understand, but I feel like there's a really large gap between the two templates. (And yeah, I understand that basic is supposed to be a completely empty template for adding user content.) If someone wants to publish a template that includes a Hello Kitty background and color scheme, that shouldn't be part of the builtin template system. But you're really missing something with just those two templates.

Creating and managing templates requires someone to understand jinja2 templating and CSS enough to know what they're doing.

I work with a bunch of electrical engineers who are really technically savvy in their field but are not very proficient in software installation and configuration, and even the simple task of "just download this template and install it" is a barrier to use. The value of IPython is that I can tell them to download Anaconda Python, install it, and run "ipython notebook" and instantly they have an environment where there is a low barrier to entry for exploring Python interactively. I don't have to write up detailed instructions and have to spend time fixing a screwed-up install, because It Just Works. Along these lines, I'm glad the interactive export to HTML is planned: (from the nbconvert docs)

> Currently, nbconvert is provided as a command line tool, run as a script using IPython. A direct export capability from within the IPython Notebook web app is planned.

I just would hate to see IPython spitting out 250 kilobyte HTML files with 50KB of meat and 200KB of CSS, instead of what should really be in the 55-60KB range.

> Along these lines, I'm glad the interactive export to HTML is planned: (from the nbconvert docs)

Ah yes, that feature has already been implemented in master (thanks @takluyver) and will be available in 3.0 when it is released.

Can you work out what CSS is actually unnecessary in there? It may be that we're erroneously shipping CSS that exported notebooks never use. On the other hand, 200 KB is practically nothing to send around nowadays, so I don't think we want to start refactoring the HTML and CSS to trim it - it's only worth doing if there's a big chunk of CSS that can easily be dropped without changing the result.

> start refactoring the HTML and CSS to trim it

^ yeah that.  nbconvert is just inline our minified style.css.  We'd need to compile another css file specific to the nbconvert output.  See the following which shows what gets embedded:

https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/master/IPython/nbconvert/preprocessors/csshtmlheader.py#L55

The more logical behavior if you have a network connection is to include the CSS by URL instead of inlining it. It won't look right if you don't have a network connection, but it ought to turn 200k into ~100B in each file.
Does that style.css include all of our UI style? Should we be compiling two separate CSS files, one for documents and one for UI?

> include the CSS by URL instead of inlining it

Just use nbviewer or an internal nbviewer deployment instead of using nbconvert directly. 

> Does that style.css include all of our UI style? Should we be compiling two separate CSS files, one for documents and one for UI?

A lot of it, yes.  And no, because the widgets use a lot of the UI styling too.  When persistence is merged we will need that styling.
But they don't need the styling for our logos, menus, toolbars, etc. I don't know how much that is, though.
No but they need the bootstrap styling, which I'm guessing is the majority of it.
